I would think the soprano voice, which usually has the melody, could do most anything.  In the song 'Over the Rainbow' the melody starts with a leap of an octave.    some...where ^....

Instructor's Post
Pee Anne Oh, in this situation, we were given the soprano note. If we were also given the alto note as F in the third chord, then the tenor would have no choice and it makes sense to say that the 'smallest' possible interval would be that jump to a sixth. Input.threadtitle: Bar 6 Last Chord -- Acceptable Variant or Not?
Input.posts:
Yes, it is acceptable. Prof. Edwards gave two ways to move between chords a fifth apart:  (A) retain the common tone and move the other voices stepwise or (B) move the three upper voices in similar motion to the nearest tones of the next triad. There is third, less common, way as well: (C) retain the common tone, move the third of the first triad up or down a fourth to the third of the next triad, and move the other voice stepwise..

Hi Bruce. The same question was posted in another thread. I mentioned there that this is acceptable. The reason why the non-common tone method is preferably chosen is that, when doing voice leading, we should try to achieve moving the voices step-wise or at the smallest interval possible. We use the non-common tone method here in favour of moving the alto and tenor at an interval of a third, whereas in your answer the tenor moved at an interval of a fourth. I'd like to continue the discussion though. How would you change the next chords so that the voice leading will be correct?
